    <dc:identifier xsi:type="dct:URI">http://www.pbs.org/parents/earlymath/grades_games_timetomove.html</dc:identifier>
    <dc:title>Time to Move</dc:title>
    <dc:description>This online interactive game helps students learn to measure and compare the lengths of different fish to determine if they belong in a big fish tank or a small one. Students catch fish with their virtual nets, measure them using a ruler, compare the length of the fish against standards for the type of fish they caught, and determine which tank is best for that fish.</dc:description>
    <dc:subject>Measurement</dc:subject>

<nsdl_dc:nsdl_dc xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:dct="http://purl.org/dc/terms/" xmlns:ieee="http://www.ieee.org/xsd/LOMv1p0" xmlns:nsdl_dc="http://ns.nsdl.org/nsdl_dc_v1.02/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" schemaVersion="1.02.020" xsi:schemaLocation="http://ns.nsdl.org/nsdl_dc_v1.02/ http://ns.nsdl.org/schemas/nsdl_dc/nsdl_dc_v1.02.xsd">
    <dc:identifier xsi:type="dct:URI">http://www.shodor.org/interactivate/activities/FractionSorter/</dc:identifier>
    <dc:title>Fraction Sorter</dc:title>
    <dc:description>Using this applet, the student represents two to four fractions by dividing and shading areas of squares or circles and then ordering the fractions from smallest to largest on a number line. The applet checks if a fraction is correctly modeled and keeps score for the student through a series of problems. A student exploration worksheet and worksheets for students to record their results are included. Related resources for teachers and further activities for students are linked from the site.</dc:description>

<nsdl_dc:nsdl_dc xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:dct="http://purl.org/dc/terms/" xmlns:ieee="http://www.ieee.org/xsd/LOMv1p0" xmlns:nsdl_dc="http://ns.nsdl.org/nsdl_dc_v1.02/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" schemaVersion="1.02.020" xsi:schemaLocation="http://ns.nsdl.org/nsdl_dc_v1.02/ http://ns.nsdl.org/schemas/nsdl_dc/nsdl_dc_v1.02.xsd">
    <dc:identifier xsi:type="dct:URI">http://math2.org/math/geometry/areasvols.htm</dc:identifier>
    <dc:title>Areas, Volumes, Surface Areas</dc:title>
    <dc:description>This printable sheet is an excellent reference tool for geometry students. It details the formulae for finding the area, volume, and surface area for a variety of two- and three-dimensional shapes and includes an illustration of each that shows which measurements are important to the calculation. Presented are: areas of polygons (square, rectangle, parallelogram, trapezoid, circle, ellipse, triangles); volumes of polyhedra (cube, rectangular prism, irregular prism, cylinder, pyramid, cone, sphere, ellipsoid); and surface area (cube, prism, sphere).</dc:description>
    <dc:subject>Measurement</dc:subject>

<nsdl_dc:nsdl_dc xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:dct="http://purl.org/dc/terms/" xmlns:ieee="http://www.ieee.org/xsd/LOMv1p0" xmlns:nsdl_dc="http://ns.nsdl.org/nsdl_dc_v1.02/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" schemaVersion="1.02.020" xsi:schemaLocation="http://ns.nsdl.org/nsdl_dc_v1.02/ http://ns.nsdl.org/schemas/nsdl_dc/nsdl_dc_v1.02.xsd">
    <dc:identifier xsi:type="dct:URI">http://www.regentsprep.org/Regents/math/geometry/GP11/PracSimPfs.htm</dc:identifier>
    <dc:title>Practice with Similarity Proofs</dc:title>
    <dc:description>In this worksheet of eight questions, students practice their knowledge of similarity proofs. In the first four questions, students determine which postulate or theorem works to prove triangle similarity - AA, SAS, or SSS. In the last four questions, students are asked to work through the proof of various problems. The answers are embedded in the page, and this is a helpful resource for students to work with similarity proofs.</dc:description>

    <dc:identifier xsi:type="dct:URI">http://www.theteacherscorner.net/printable-worksheets/make-your-own/math-worksheets/basic-math/fractions-equations.php</dc:identifier>
    <dc:title>Make Your Own Fractions Worksheet</dc:title>
    <dc:description>This page, from The Teacher's Corner, allows educators to quickly make worksheets for students to practice addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division of fractions. Teachers can specify one or more fraction operation, the title, instructions, number of problems, ranges of numerators and denominators, and much more. Worksheets are automatically generated in printable form, and the answer key is on the second page, if desired. Teachers are also encouraged to offer feedback at the bottom of the page.</dc:description>

<nsdl_dc:nsdl_dc xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:dct="http://purl.org/dc/terms/" xmlns:ieee="http://www.ieee.org/xsd/LOMv1p0" xmlns:nsdl_dc="http://ns.nsdl.org/nsdl_dc_v1.02/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" schemaVersion="1.02.020" xsi:schemaLocation="http://ns.nsdl.org/nsdl_dc_v1.02/ http://ns.nsdl.org/schemas/nsdl_dc/nsdl_dc_v1.02.xsd">
    <dc:identifier xsi:type="dct:URI">http://www.teachervision.fen.com/tv/printables/allynbacon/JVW_3_5_Ch9_Section12.pdf</dc:identifier>
    <dc:title>Fixed Areas</dc:title>
    <dc:description>In this activity, students explore area and perimeter, the difference between them, and how to calculate them. As an introductory activity, students are given 12 tiles and asked to design a rectangle from them and uncover the definitions of area and perimeter. Then, students are given 36 tiles and asked to create as many rectangles as possible, observing the dimensions, area, and perimeter of each. A worksheet is provided, along with centimeter and half-centimeter grid paper.</dc:description>
